respondent.name: CITY OF CHICAGO, ILLINOIS, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We’ll hear argument first this morning in Case 08-1521, McDonald v. The City of Chicago. Mr. Gura.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of course, this argument is contrary to the Slaughter-House Cases, which have been the law for 140 years. It might be simpler, but it's a big -- it's a heavy burden for you to carry to suggest that we ought to overrule that decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What injustice has -- has been caused by it that we have to remedy? Meaning States have relied on having no grand juries; States have relied on not having civil trials in certain money cases; they have relied on regulating the use of firearms based on us, the Court, not incorporating the Privileges and Immunities Clause in the way that you identify it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What -- in which ways has ordered liberty been badly affected?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you saying that the rights -- if you could clarify your conception of privileges and immunities. Am I right in thinking that to keep and bear arms would be included even if we had no Second Amendment, as you envision privileges and immunities?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But -- just tell us the dimensions of what it is. I mean, we have the eight amendments, so I know you say that's included. Keep and bear arms would be included even absent the Second Amendment. What unenumerated rights would we be declaring privileges and immunities under your conception of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Gura, do you think it’s at all easier to bring the Second Amendment under the Privileges and Immunities Clause than it is to bring it under our established law of substantive due process?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is it easier to do it under privileges and immunities than it is under substantive due process?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, no. I'm not talking about whether -- whether the Slaughter-House Cases were right or wrong. I'm saying, assuming we give, you know, the Privileges and Immunities Clause your definition, does that make it any easier to get the Second Amendment adopted with respect to the States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if the answer is no, why are you asking us to overrule 150, 140 years of prior law, when -- when you can reach your result under substantive due -- I mean, you know, unless you’re bucking for a -- a place on some law school faculty -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I mean, what you argue is the darling of the professoriate, for sure, but it's also contrary to 140 years of our jurisprudence. Why do you want to undertake that burden instead of just arguing substantive due process? Which, as much as I think it's wrong, I have -- even I have acquiesced in it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that -- that court does not have the prerogative to overturn any of this Court's decisions, and I think it said -- said as much. So it was kind of a pass-through in the court of appeals. But I really would like you to answer the question that you didn't have an opportunity to finish answering, and that is: What other enumerated rights? What does the privileges and immunities of United States citizenship embrace?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Even though -- even though a large portion of the population at that time didn't have those rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: No, throughout -- throughout the nation at the time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did married women at that time across the nation have the right to contract, to hold property, to sue and be sued?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Does it work just one way? I mean, if the notion is that these are principles that any free society would adopt, well, a lot of free societies have rejected the right to keep and bear arms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But this -- then it's not one expression of this unenumerated rights, natural rights, or the rights that any free society -- basic to a free society. So you -- you have to trim your definition. It's not basic to any free society.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what about rights rooted in the traditions and conscience of our people? Would -- would that do the job?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That happens to be the test we have used under substantive due process.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Gura, can I ask you the same question Justice Ginsburg asked about: What if there were no Second Amendment? You say the right would still be protected under the Privileges and Immunities Clause. What about -- would it also be protected under substantive due process if there were no Second Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because of the -- the importance of the right to protection -- and would that apply to the entire scope of the Second Amendment or just the right to keep the gun, a homeowner's right to keep a gun for self-protection against intruders into the home, under the -- without the Second Amendment, just the Liberty Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm assuming we don't have a Second Amendment for purposes of the substantive due process analysis. I'm asking you what is the scope of the right to own a gun that is protected by the Liberty Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment? Is it just the right to have it at -- at home, or is the right to parade around the streets with guns?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I thought your --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In -- in that context, is your position that the rights that are incorporated as essential to the concept of ordered liberty, do they bring all of our decisions with them? When you say the First Amendment is covered, does that mean New York Times v. Sullivan is incorporated as well? Or is it only some lesser version of the incorporated right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, I understood the Chief Justice's question -- maybe I misunderstood it, but my understanding of the question as important is this: Under incorporation by reference, the States are bound by the rights in all -- with all of the refinements and sophistication with which we interpret them for the Federal Government. It's the same. You don't just apply the core of the right. You apply all of the right as it is elaborated by the cases. Is -- is that same consequence -- does that same consequence follow if we adopt the privileges and immunities interpretation that you are urging upon us?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. How does that work? I think that would be useful for either you or Mr. Clement, if you've thought this through. Is this right different from others?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There are two ways. One is that -- look at -- all you have to do is look at the briefs. Look at the statistics. You know, one side says a million people killed by guns. Chicago says that their -- their gun law has saved hundreds, including -- and they have statistics -- including lots of women in domestic cases. And the other side disputes it. This is a highly statistical matter. Without incorporation, it's decided by State legislatures; with, it's decided by Federal judges. Now, think of this, too: That when you have the First Amendment, or some of the other amendments, there’s always a big area where it's free speech versus a whole lot of things, but not often free speech versus life. When it's free speech versus life, we very often decide in favor of life. Here every case will be on one side guns, on the other side human life. Statistics, balancing life versus guns. How are Federal judges in your opinion, rather than legislatures in the States in a Federal system -- how are Federal judges supposed to carry this out? I want to see where we’re going.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Heller, I didn't think, explained that with great -- I was dissenting, though. I didn't think it explained it with total clarity, but that's a dissenter's view. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let me be specific, suppose Chicago says, look, by banning handguns not in the hills, not hunting, nothing like that, nothing outside the city -- in the city, we save several hundred human lives every year. And the other side says, we don't think it is several hundred, and, moreover, that doesn't matter. How do you decide the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You’re saying they can have -- no matter what, that the City just can't have guns even if they’re saving hundreds of lives -- they can’t ban them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There’s a lot of statistical disagreement on whether the Miranda rule saves lives or not, whether it results in the release of dangerous people who have confessed to their crime, but the confession can't be used. We don't -- we don't resolve questions like that on the basis of statistics, do we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why would this one be resolved on the basis of statistics? If there’s a constitutional right, we find what the minimum constitutional right is, and everything above that is up to the States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If they want to have, you know -- I think we mentioned in Heller concealed carry laws. I mean, those are -- those are matters that we didn't decide in Heller. And you may have a great deal of divergence from State to State. And on that, I suppose, you would do statistics, wouldn't you? Or the legislature would.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For the judges. For the judges.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But they would be for the legislatures.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Clement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, would you comment on Justice Kennedy's question about whether that necessarily incorporates every jot and tittle of the Federal right into the Federal, keeping in mind that with regard to trial by jury in criminal cases, there’s a difference. It’s nonunanimous juries. Why does this incorporation have to be every bit as broad as the Second Amendment itself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, what is the last case in which we incorporated a substantive provision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mapp was a procedural case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mapp was a Fourth Amendment case. I'm asking you cases involving incorporation of substantive rights, as opposed to procedural rights.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The procedural cases come in under the due process language, but the substantive cases comes under the word "liberty," and "liberty" picks up the First Amendment and so forth. And I take it it's the word "liberty" that picks up the Second Amendment. And if it does, why does it have to be precisely the same scope as the Second Amendment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I guess we -- I guess we have applied substantive due process with regard to the necessity of permitting homosexual conduct and with respect to the necessity of permitting abortion on demand. We have not adopted a more rigid rule for the Federal Government than we have adopted for the States in either of those instances, have we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: They stand in a favored position, but we've never said had to be literally all the way down the line, or we couldn't have done the criminal jury -- nonunanimous criminal jury case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: That's true of the criminal jury trial right, too, all of those things? And yet we don't -- it's not exactly the same. I just don't see why it has to be exactly the same. I can understand your argument that it should be substantially the same, but I don't see that there's anything in the text of the Fourteenth Amendment that would justify saying it must be precisely the same, or of any of our cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Incorporation jurisprudence is -- we haven't had an incorporation case for 30 years or more.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That still allows scope, once you determine that the right is incorporated, for recognizing that the States might have broader interests that the Federal Government doesn't have. But I would suppose that would come up in the application of the right, rather than in an effort to determine whether parts of it are incorporated or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You’re -- you’re dead right --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- about the majority of the Court, but it's interesting that during this whole period, Justice Harlan staked out a separate position on whether it should be just the substance of the right or the -- every detail. And we have followed Justice Harlan, rather than the majority in a number of cases in -- in the recent years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: He is very much against you, and he's a very important member of our -- of our history.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Maybe we should go back --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Clement, why shouldn't we go back completely to Justice Harlan's view about the way in which the Bill of Rights applies to the States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But there is a difference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There is a difference here with the other amendments. There is a difference, and the other amendments -- you have the First Amendment’s, the First Amendment expression. Here we have right in the amendment written a militia-related clause. And the way that -- the way -- the way that the right might be incorporated in respect to that is light years different from the way it might be interpreted if you think what it is, is the right to have a gun to shoot a burglar. They’re just two separate things. And as to the first, it's pretty hard for me to see why you’d incorporate it, for reasons I won't go into. As to the second, I understand it. So we’re starting with a difference in purposes at the least. And shouldn't that make a difference in how you incorporate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because the -- one of the reasons --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- at least, is that -- you’ve read, I'm sure, that all the law professors at Harvard, Yale, Princeton, London, et cetera, that say even Blackstone in the 17th century thought that this is primarily a right to raise an army through Parliament to -- well, I can't go on here. I'm just saying think of that brief, and you’ll see the differences, even accepting Heller.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You can respond if you want, briefly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Clement. Mr. Feldman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When is the last time an opinion of ours made that the test, implicit in the concept of ordered liberty? It sounds very nice. But when is the last time we used it? I think it was 1937.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Has it been the basis of our decision in any case since Palko?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And it was also the Harlan view, although a separate opinion in the Griswold case and in Poe v. Ullman. Do you think that it best describes the approach that the Court has used over the years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I was going to ask Mr. Clement what test he thought the Court used. If you looked at all the cases, you think implicit in the concept of ordered liberty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is the right to trial by jury implicit in the concept of ordered liberty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: My goodness --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- there are a lot of countries that don't give the right to trial by jury, even England does not give it in all criminal cases.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I think that's exactly -- that's exactly right. And that is what the Court elaborated on in Duncan. I do think the focus is our system of ordered liberty, not any abstract system of ordered liberty. You can say Japan is a free country, but it doesn't have the right to trial by -- by jury. The -- the concept only makes sense, I think, if you limit it to our system. Under our system, as you said, the -- the right to a jury is essential.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, if you think that's right, why wouldn't you think, for all the reasons given in Heller, that the Second Amendment right is essential to our system, whatever it may be with respect to France or England or anywhere else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I thought its rationale was that because of its fundamental character, the right to bear arms must be understood as separate from the qualifying phrase of the militia clause, all people, most people in the United States. The public meaning of the Second Amendment was that there was an individual right to bear arms, and that's because it was fundamental. If it's not fundamental, then Heller is wrong, it seems to me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't see how you can read --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't see how you can read Heller and not take away from it the notion that the Second Amendment, whether you’d want to label it fundamental or not, was extremely important to the framers in their view of what liberty meant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That may be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That may be the reason it was put there. But it was put there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's the crucial fact. It is either there or it is not there. And if it's there, it doesn't seem to me to make any difference why they chose to put that one there as opposed to other ones that they didn't put there. It's either there or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So do we read the -- the clause at the beginning -- the militia clause -- we’re supposed to read the words of the Constitution, aren't we? I guess --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the answer to that’s yes. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Thank you. Very well, and doesn't that suggest what the purpose of putting the right there is even under Heller or at least one purpose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And does that not give us a clue as to what they thought that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the ordered liberty was? That's your point?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, sure, and it's still going to be subject to the political process if the Court determines that it’s incorporated in the Due Process Clause. All the arguments you make against incorporation, it seems to me, are arguments you should make in favor of regulation under the Second Amendment. We haven't said anything about what the content of the Second Amendment is beyond what was said in Heller.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And so the argument you make is, well, given this context, you should not be able to have concealed carry. Well, maybe that's right, but that doesn't mean you don't incorporate the Second Amendment to allow you to enforce that type of regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And your position is that a -- a State or local government could completely ban all firearms?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I -- I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What is the due process liberty --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What basis would there be to -- to deny that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Firearms kill people is what the States say, and -- and we ban it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Other countries have done that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But if they did do it, I think you’d have to say it's perfectly okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. The reason is guns are dangerous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But would self-defense be part of liberty under the Due -- substantive meaning of the Due Process Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And you’ve given -- you said there were two reasons. So you have given us both in your answer to Justice Alito's question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Without repeating that and just so I understand your position, how could some member of the Court write the -- this opinion to say that this right is not fundamental, but that Heller was correct?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That sounds an awful lot to me like the argument we heard in Heller on the losing side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They said that is the reason it was codified. They did not say that that is the function of what was codified. The function of what was codified was to enforce the traditional right of the people to bear arms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And to say that that wasn't the reason it was codified doesn't say anything about what it consists of.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Let me see if I understand your argument. I thought you said a minute ago that if a State or local government were to ban firearms completely, this Court might hold that that violates substantive due process because the right to use a firearm for self-defense is -- might be held to be implicit in the concept of ordered liberty; is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And -- but I thought you began by saying that the right to keep and bear arms is not implicit in the concept of ordered liberty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Feldman, let me take your argument at -- at its face value. Let's assume that the only reason it is there and the only purpose it serves is the militia purpose. Isn't that militia purpose just as much defeated by allowing the States to take away the militia's arms as it would be by allowing the Federal Government to take away the militia's arms?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Then so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- even if you assume that the whole thing turns around the militia prologue, that prologue is just as -- just as important with respect to the State's depriving the people of arms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You’re switching horses now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Let's just focus on your argument that -- that -- that deals with the prologue. You say this is different because of that prologue. But that prologue has just as much force if the States take away the militia's arms as if the Federal Government does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, suppose it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- Suppose it is. Assume for argument's sake that it is. Still, I take from what you are saying that -- let's make up an imaginary importance of ordered liberty chart, and we give it to James Madison and the other framers. And he would say, insofar as that right to bear arms is important for the purpose of maintaining the militia, it's high on the ordered liberty chart. Insofar as the right to bear arms is there to shoot burglars, it's low on the ordered liberty chart. And if that's what they’d say, it's conceivable that part of this amendment would go through and be incorporated; namely, that part which would prevent a law that would disarm people to the extent they couldn't form militias. But that part which would disarm people to the extent that they couldn't shoot burglars, that would not be incorporated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But if we took the approach that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If we took the approach that Justice Breyer outlined, would -- why would we not do the same thing with respect to all the applications of all of the amendments that up to this point have been regarded as being completely incorporated, along with all of our decisions? So why would we not look at all of our decisions under the First Amendment and the Fourth Amendment and the Fifth Amendment and the Sixth Amendment, and rank all of those interpretations on some scale of ordered liberty?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, to get back to Justice Breyer's point, which I'm not sure you answered, is your theory that you simply -- it's not a question of is it in or is it out? But you’re saying, well, what is in and what is out, are you?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So you think it's in or out, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, I -- I know your reasons.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm trying to get you to take a position on whether or not you want us to not only pick and choose among which amendments are part of our abstract notion of ordered liberty, or if you want us also to take amendments that might be in and refine them and shave them off a little bit and say, well, this part of the amendment is in, and this part isn't.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. So your argument is all in or all out.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Step one -- step one is make my chart. Step two is look at what's high. Step three is, even though that high part, even that high part, nobody could think was incorporated.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's how you think Madison went about his job? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He did, actually. He did. That's how he went about it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm asking counsel. Do you think that's how Madison went about his job?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Feldman, our selective incorporation doctrine under the Due Process Clause does suggest that there are some rights that were fundamental enough to be incorporated and some that are fundamental, but not fundamental enough to be incorporated. We’ve drawn a line. Is it the ordered liberty concept alone in our jurisprudence that you are relying upon, or is it any other articulation of our incorporation doctrine that supports your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The Chief says: Yes, if we look at it, we have to look at it in the context of our history, our structure. So address his question as to why --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- in our structure or our history, it's not fundamental enough --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- to incorporate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Eleven of the colonies had a guarantee at the time the Constitution was adopted, and I believe something like 44 States currently have in their constitutions protection of the right to bear arms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does that suggest anything about -- about how fundamental it is generally?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: "Subject to such regulation" certainly excludes banning them entirely, which is what you assert can be done.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's the purpose of a State constitutional guarantee which has at the end of it "subject to such regulation as the legislature may proscribe," if that regulation includes banning it entirely? That --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- would make a nullity of the constitutional requirement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And is that what you’re asserting here --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that the States have to allow firearms?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't think so, either, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- why does your last argument make any sense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's fine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We said as much in Heller.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, all those may be perfectly valid today, or -- if the Court incorporates the Second Amendment. Incorporation doesn't say anything by itself about whether those types of regulations, which you think are reasonable and your friends think may not be reasonable, are valid or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Handguns in the home?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Handguns in the home? That's what Heller addressed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, you can't, because they didn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But there -- but there are provisions of the Constitution, of the Bill of Rights, that have been incorporated against the States, where the States have substantial latitude and ample authority to impose reasonable regulations, rights respecting -- rights respecting property, the Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause. We look to see what the political process does. We look to see -- why can't we do the same thing with firearms?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you think there is existing authority with reference to other provisions of the Bill of Rights that would allow us to incorporate just the core of Heller with respect to the States? Just the core of the Second Amendment with respect to the States, along the lines to this question Justice Stevens was asking earlier?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And if so, what's -- what case do we look to for that proposition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If you look to Justice Harlan's dissent in Griswold, where he says the Fourteenth Amendment stands on its own bottom and it can be either more or less than the provisions of the Bill of Rights, and there’s no reason in the world why this Court could not adopt the same position here and say: Insofar it’s incorporated, it applies only within the home. The Court had ample precedent for that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. Is it the position of the City of Chicago that we should rely on Justice Harlan's dissent in Griswold?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, then your answer to Justice Stevens is no, you’re not going to follow that approach, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: See, the right to keep and bear arms is right there. It's right there in the Bill of Rights. Where do you find the right to self-defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you want us to impose that one on the States but not -- not the explicit guarantee of the right to keep and bear arms. That seems very strange.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The District of Columbia did. That’s what Heller said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Would you be happy if we incorporated it and said reasonable regulation is part of the incorporation? And how do we do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that Heller -- Heller allowed for reasonable regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that the Heller decision allowed for reasonable regulation, and it gave a few examples, as Justice Scalia mentioned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What you’re urging is really a mixed blessing for gun control advocates. To the extent we sever the Federal guarantee from what the States are obliged to comport with, we encourage a stricter Federal Second Amendment, one that forbids all sorts of regulations that the Federal Government might otherwise be allowed to do, because it doesn't matter -- the States can take care of it. I mean, you know, if -- if you sever the two, you’re encouraging a broader prohibition at the Federal level, and that's what -- Heller was very careful not to impose such a broad prohibition precisely because it realized that -- that this is a national problem.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Gura, you have 3 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Counsel, at the -- at the very outset of your argument, Justice Sotomayor asked the question which, as I understood it, essentially said what are examples of privileges and immunities that are being denied by the States that -- which denial would be remedied by following your proposal to overrule the Slaughter-House case? And let's leave the Second Amendment out. Let's assume the Second Amendment is a wash; it's either going to be incorporated or not going to be incorporated the same -- to the same extent under either the Privileges or Immunities Clause or the Due Process Clause. Leaving the Due Process -- the Second Amendment out of it, what privileges and immunities are now being denied citizens of -- of the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What are examples of those? The jury trial in civil cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And grand jury. What else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you are saying that under -- under your view, every State would have to use a grand jury to bring criminal charges; no more information. And that every State would have to have a civil jury, if any party in the case requested it. Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's a criminal case; that's quite different.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'm -- we’re using up your time. But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- do you want me to leave the bench thinking grand jury indictment and civil trial and jury case -- that's it. There's no other -- what are these other unenumerated rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't trouble you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, does it include the right to contract?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Isn't that an unenumerated right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Your approach -- your original approach would give judges a lot more power and flexibility in determining what rights they think are a good idea than they have now with the constraints of the Due Process Clause.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Privileges and immunities give you a lot more flexibility than due process, because it’s not limited to procedural -- where you don't have to deal with the hurdle that it's limited to procedural by the text.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, you may.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
